title: The NYT mini v ChatGPT
text:
To test ChatGPT‚Äôs ability to solve crossword puzzles, I gave it the New York Times mini crossword and analyzed how it approached the clues. The goal was to see how well ChatGPT could infer words based on definitions and whether it could adjust when errors were identified. I also wanted to test if Chatgpt could understand the interactions between different words in columns and rows that intersect.


ChatGPT‚Äôs First Attempt
Below is the crossword we are using for this test. It is Superbowl-themed (GO BIRDS) and over my past couple of years of doing the mini every day - I would say today is one of the easier ones. If I had to give it a Roytman-certified difficulty level it would be a 3/10.

ChatGPT initially provided the following answers:

1A: CAT ‚úÖ (Correct)
4A: CHIEF ‚úÖ (Correct)
6A: LAMAR ‚úÖ (Correct)
7A: FOE ‚ùå (Incorrect)
8A: TDS ‚úÖ (Correct)
1D: CHANT ‚úÖ (Correct)
2D: THREW ‚úÖ (Correct)
3D: CASTS ‚úÖ (Correct)
4D: CLE ‚úÖ (Correct)
5D: FRY ‚úÖ (Correct)

The issue was with 7 Across (Opposing side), where ChatGPT suggested FOE, which didn‚Äôt fit correctly with 5 Down (Cook in the pan ‚Üí FRY).



First Correction
After ChatGPT messed up I attempted to fix its mistake, giving it the following prompt: ‚ÄúTake into account the fact that the interactions between the two words. For example, Foe cant be 7a cause the row is 5 letters and the other letters in that word dont match. Solve it in regards to that not just the clue hints.‚Äù
While Chat GPT did correctly replace FOE with a 5-letter word, it still did not align correctly with the ending letter of FRY.
Here‚Äôs ChatGPT‚Äôs incorrect revision:




Final Correction
Once I highlighted that the revised answer still didn‚Äôt match, ChatGPT finally adjusted 7 Across to ENEMY, which correctly fit the crossword constraints. I specifically pointed it out by prompting it with ‚Äúthe L in rival does not match with the Y in fry‚Äù. Chat GPT‚Äôs final correct response is below:

It seems that if I point out a specific letter mismatch, chat GPT is finally able to solve it. However, it is important to note that this is Chat GPT‚Äôs third attempt - meaning that through trial and error ‚Äúenemy‚Äù may have been the only possible option remaining.



Conclusion: Strengths and Weaknesses of ChatGPT in Crossword Solving

Strengths:

ChatGPT correctly inferred most words based on the clues.

It recognized word associations effectively (e.g., ‚ÄúBengal or lion‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúCAT‚Äù).

It could adapt and revise answers based on feedback.

Weaknesses:

ChatGPT initially failed to check if its answers aligned across the grid.

Even after a revision, it still made a mistake by choosing a word of incorrect length.

Human intervention was required to get to the final correct solution, which may have resulted from trial and error.


Overall, ChatGPT demonstrated strong linguistic reasoning and clue interpretation but struggled with spatial constraints, showing that while AI can assist in solving crosswords, human verification is still necessary.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text: In our last in-class assignment I mentioned the Upenn campus and independently chatGPT mentioned biking down Walnut Street. This made me curious about how well Chatgpt can actually evaluate geographic contexts. In this post I will conduct a series of experiments by providing various locations and evaluating the model‚Äôs responses on different geographic aspects. This analysis will help us understand the strengths and limitations of LLMs in geographic reasoning and potential use cases for real-world applications.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text: In our last in-class assignment I mentioned the Upenn campus and independently chatGPT mentioned biking down Walnut Street. This made me curious about how well Chatgpt can actually evaluate geographic contexts. In this post I will conduct a series of experiments by providing various locations and evaluating the model‚Äôs responses on different geographic aspects. This analysis will help us understand the strengths and limitations of LLMs in geographic reasoning and potential use cases for real-world applications.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text:
Penn Campus Ball Knowledge
First we are going to test for basic knowledge, then will ask increasingly more specific and context-based questions. We will start this experiment with its origin: Upenn Campus.
I first asked ‚ÄúWhat are the major landmarks located around Upenn‚Äôs Campus‚Äù
Chatgpt gave a surprisingly contextualized answer. The response was:
‚ÄúThe University of Pennsylvania (Penn) is located in the heart of Philadelphia‚Äôs University City neighborhood, and it is surrounded by several major landmarks. Here are some of the most notable ones:

On or Adjacent to Penn‚Äôs Campus

Locust Walk ‚Äì A pedestrian pathway that runs through the heart of Penn‚Äôs campus, lined with historic buildings and student activity hubs.
Fisher Fine Arts Library ‚Äì A striking red brick and terracotta building designed by Frank Furness, one of the most beautiful libraries on campus.
The Quad (University of Pennsylvania College Houses) ‚Äì A historic dormitory complex that houses many first-year students.
Penn Museum (University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology) ‚Äì One of the world‚Äôs most renowned archaeology and anthropology museums, featuring collections from ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia, and more.
The Palestra ‚Äì A historic basketball arena known as the ‚ÄúCathedral of College Basketball.‚Äù
Franklin Field ‚Äì The nation‚Äôs oldest operating football stadium, home to Penn‚Äôs football team and the Penn Relays.
Van Pelt Library ‚Äì Penn‚Äôs central library, offering extensive research resources.
Irvine Auditorium ‚Äì A historic venue for performances, lectures, and events, featuring stunning stained-glass windows.
Singh Center for Nanotechnology ‚Äì A state-of-the-art research facility with unique modern architecture.
Perelman Center for Advanced Medicine ‚Äì A top medical research and treatment facility affiliated with Penn Medicine.



Nearby Landmarks in University City

30th Street Station ‚Äì A major Amtrak and regional rail hub, just a short walk from campus.
Cira Centre & Cira Green ‚Äì A rooftop park with great views of the city skyline, located near 30th Street Station.
Schuylkill River Trail ‚Äì A scenic walking, running, and biking trail along the Schuylkill River.
The Philadelphia Museum of Art & Rocky Steps ‚Äì Located a short distance away along the Benjamin Franklin Parkway.
Drexel University ‚Äì Penn‚Äôs neighboring university, located just to the north of campus.

Would you like recommendations on things to see or do around campus?‚Äù
I was pleasantly surprised by this answer, however, I think its level of knowledge is still less than a Upenn student‚Äôs. Specifically, if I were to ask a Penn student for landmarks around campus they probably wouldn‚Äôt mention ‚ÄúThe Palestra‚Äù and ‚ÄúSingh Center for Nanotechnology‚Äù nor would they mention any dorms/lecture halls. They would maybe mention something that is more intrinsic to Penn culture like Ben Frank. Also for nearby landmarks, I doubt a Penn student would say Drexel or 30th Street Station and maybe would answer Rittenhouse Square. Because of this, I am going to follow up and ask the following question:
Now answer in the context of a Upenn student, what would you describe as 5 community staples of Penn Campus.
Chatgpt answered with the following:
‚ÄúAs a Penn student, five community staples on campus that define the Penn experience would be:

Locust Walk ‚Äì The heart of campus life, where students pass through daily to get to class, stop by club tables, or run into friends. During events like Spring Fling and Hey Day, it transforms into a hub of celebration.
Houston Hall ‚Äì The country‚Äôs first student union and a go-to spot for students to grab food, study, or meet up with friends. It houses several dining options, study spaces, and is home to many student organization meetings.
The Quad (University of Pennsylvania College Houses) ‚Äì A defining first-year experience. Living in the Quad is almost a rite of passage, and the iconic red-brick buildings and central green spaces make it a central community hub for freshmen.
Van Pelt Library ‚Äì The ultimate study spot with a space for every type of student, from the bustling first floor to the silence of the sixth. Students often joke about ‚Äúliving‚Äù here during finals season.
Wawa (38th & Spruce) ‚Äì More than just a convenience store, this Wawa is a beloved late-night food stop for Penn students. Whether it‚Äôs post-party hoagies, a quick coffee before class, or a mid-study snack run, this location is a true campus staple.

Each of these places holds a special significance in student life, creating shared experiences that define the Penn community. Would you like recommendations for more niche or lesser-known spots?‚Äù
With this ‚ÄúPenn student‚Äù directive language, Chatgpt actually gave a really good answer. All of the locations that it mentioned are trademarks of the Upenn experience - particularly the iconic freshmen one. On top of that, I think knowing Quadwa is a nice cherry on top.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text:
WHERE DO I GO???
Now that we have tested ChatGPTs ability to understand what is around Penn campus, we will test its ability to get ME around Penn Campus. Similar to last experiment we will start with an easy question and move up in dificulty. I started by asking ChatGPT:
‚ÄúIf I am at Rodin college house what is the most optimal way to get to Houston Hall as a Upenn Student.‚Äù
ChatGPT gave the following response:
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre at Rodin College House, the most optimal way to get to Houston Hall as a Penn student would be:

Primary Route (Fastest & Most Direct) ‚Äì Approx. 7 min Walk

Exit Rodin and head south on 40th Street toward Locust Walk.
Turn left (east) onto Locust Walk and continue straight.
Walk along Locust Walk, passing Harrison College House, Gutmann College House, and the Quad.
Houston Hall is on your left just before reaching 36th Street.

This route is the best because: - Locust Walk is pedestrian-friendly and the main thoroughfare of campus. - It‚Äôs a scenic route where you‚Äôll likely run into friends or student organizations tabling. - It‚Äôs well-lit and safe, making it a great option even at night.


Alternative Route (Bad Weather or Indoor Option)
If it‚Äôs raining or too cold, you can modify your route slightly: 1. Walk through the high-rises (Harrison, Harnwell, or Gutmann) and cut over to Locust Walk via Gutmann‚Äôs indoor connector. 2. Continue on Locust Walk to Houston Hall.
Would you like an optimized route for any other locations?‚Äù
Chatgpt messed up a couple of times in these directions. First, when you exit Rodin you can only go onto Locust Walk, meaning it‚Äôs not only unnecessary to go to 40th Street first, but it is impossible. On top of that, you would not pass Gutmann College house on the way. However, this situation might not be entirely ChatGPT‚Äôs fault; often when I plug in a college hall in Apple or Google Maps it will give me a more inefficient way of not using Locust - implying that Locust Walk might be the problem. I will ask ChatGPT how to get from 4040 Walnut Street to David Rittenhouse Laboratory to test that.
ChatGPT Responded with:
‚ÄúTo get from 4040 Walnut Street to David Rittenhouse Laboratory (DRL) in the most optimal way as a Penn student, follow this route (~7 min walk):


Primary Route (Fastest & Most Direct)

Start at 4040 Walnut Street and walk east (toward Center City) on Walnut Street.
Continue straight on Walnut Street for four blocks, passing 40th St, 39th St, and 38th St.
When you reach 33rd Street, turn left (north) onto 33rd Street.
David Rittenhouse Laboratory (DRL) is immediately on your right, at 209 S 33rd St.



Alternative Route (Scenic Campus Walk)

Walk south on 40th Street toward Locust Walk.
Turn left (east) onto Locust Walk and walk straight through campus.
Pass Gutmann College House, the Quad, and the Penn Bookstore.
At 33rd Street, turn left, and DRL will be straight ahead.

Which route is better? - The Walnut Street route is the fastest and most direct. - The Locust Walk route is more scenic and lets you walk through the heart of campus.
Let me know if you need directions to another spot!‚Äù
Its primary route is accurate, suggesting that Locust may have been the problem with the original experiment. However, when it suggested a scenic campus walk, it was correct about the directions but was wrong about passing the Penn Bookstore along the way. This suggests that it was able to figure out the exact directions but didn‚Äôt have the spatial awareness to understand the landscape on the way.

title: Can ChatGPT Get me to class?
text:
Conclusion
ChatGPT did a pretty solid job with this experiment. It was able to recognize major landmarks around Penn and even adapt its responses when prompted to think like a Penn student. While its initial answer included places like The Palestra and Singh Center, which a student probably wouldn‚Äôt think to mention, its second response nailed it with community staples like Houston Hall, Van Pelt, and Quadwa. That shows it can adjust its answers based on context, which is impressive.
On the navigation side, ChatGPT gave reasonable directions but had trouble with campus-specific details. The Rodin to Houston Hall route was a little off since it didn‚Äôt realize you can‚Äôt walk onto 40th Street directly from Rodin. But when asked about getting from 4040 Walnut to DRL, it mostly got the directions right, except for mistakenly mentioning passing the Penn Bookstore. This suggests it can process general routes well but struggles with spatial awareness of landmarks along the way.
Overall, ChatGPT can recognize Penn landmarks and generate decent walking directions, but it‚Äôs still missing some of the instinctive knowledge a real Penn student would have. It seems to rely on external mapping data rather than lived experience, which leads to small but noticeable inaccuracies. While it‚Äôs good for general guidance, if you need the best route around campus, you‚Äôre still better off asking a fellow Penn student.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: LLMs and Emotional Recognition
text:
## Introduction
This post will dive into different LLMs; most notably Deepseek, Chatgpt, and Anthropic/Claude - examining their abilities to recognize different human emotions. Each LLM will be given an image of a human person experiencing an emotion and be asked to describe what emotion said person is experiencing.

title: LLMs and Emotional Recognition
text:
Sad Woman
We are going to start by giving each model a relatively easy image of a sad woman. We will then test if Chatgpt, Deepseek, and Claude can analyze the emotion with the following prompt: what emotion is this woman experiencing.
For context the image of the woman is below:


ChatGPT
ChatGPT‚Äôs response is the following:
‚ÄúThe woman in the image appears to be experiencing boredom, sadness, or contemplation. Her facial expression, including a slightly downturned mouth, relaxed posture, and resting her head on her hand, suggests that she might be feeling uninterested, tired, or deep in thought. Let me know if you need a more detailed analysis!‚Äù
I was honestly pleasantly surprised with this result. Not only did ChatGPT correctly address that the woman is sad, but it was also able to contextualize potential other emotions the woman is experiencing. ChatGPT passes the first test.


Deepseek
Deepseek‚Äôs response is the following:
‚ÄúBased on your description of the woman in the image, it is difficult to definitively determine her exact emotion without more specific details or context. However, considering common emotions associated with women, sadness stands out as a strong possibility. Sadness can often be expressed through open arms, thoughtful gestures, or a deep contentment, depending on the situation.
If she appears to be feeling sad about something, such as her own experiences, relationships, or personal struggles, sadness could be a fitting emotion. However, without additional information, it‚Äôs hard to say for certain.‚Äù
While Deepseek was unsure about the emotion at first, it did correctly identify the emotion as sadness. However, there were some things in the response that threw me off. Specifically, its original line of reasoning was ‚Äúconsidering common emotions associated with women, sadness stands out as a strong possibility.‚Äù I found this a bit weird since a) I never told it to relate back to common traits associated with women and b) sadness (to my knowledge at least) is not a trait disproportionately associated with women to an extent that would justify guessing the women in the image was experiencing sadness. Either way Deepseek did get the emotion right, so they pass the first test.


Claude
Claude‚Äôs response is the following:
‚ÄúIn this image, the person appears to be experiencing boredom or contemplation. Their body language - resting their head on their hand while sitting - is a classic pose that suggests they‚Äôre feeling unengaged or lost in thought. They‚Äôre wearing a casual purple t-shirt and sitting in what looks like a home environment with bookshelves visible in the background.‚Äù
Claude was actually the first LLM to not comment on the woman‚Äôs sadness in the image. It is fair to note that boredom and contemplation are reasonable responses to the image as the woman is resting her head on her hand and staring off into the distance. However, if Claude analyzed her facial expressions, like the other models, then it might have been able to note her sadness. Claude partially passes.

title: LLMs and Emotional Recognition
text:
Anxious Man
Now we are going to pivot to a relatively more complex emotion: anxiety. Similar to our first test, I will provide each LLM with the following image:


ChatGPT
ChatGPT‚Äôs response is the following:
‚ÄúThe man in the image appears to be experiencing stress, worry, or deep contemplation. His facial expression, with furrowed brows and a slightly distant gaze, along with his posture‚Äîleaning forward with his hands clasped near his face‚Äîsuggests that he may be feeling anxious, troubled, or lost in thought. His body language indicates he could be dealing with a difficult situation or processing something emotionally intense. Let me know if you need a more detailed analysis!‚Äù
ChatGPT yet again passed with flying colors. It perfectly breaks down the man‚Äôs body language/facial interactions to conclude that the man is feeling anxious. Honestly, not much else to talk about here ‚Äì ChatGPT seems to be the best model at recognizing emotions.


Deepseek
Deepseek‚Äôs response is the following:
‚ÄúThe emotion experienced by the man depicted in the image can be inferred through analysis of his actions, body language, and facial expressions. Here‚Äôs a structured summary:
Happiness: Indicates open arms, cheerful eyes, and relaxed demeanor. Joyful Expression: Shows contentment, peaceful expression, or content with others‚Äô success. Calmness: A wide mouth suggests ease, suggesting a neutral or positive emotion. Sadness: Signs include deep sighs, heavy heart, slow, deep frown, and perhaps tears. Anger: Sharp teeth with expressive mouths might indicate frustration. Frustration: Telling sounds or tight focus could signify this emotion. Confusion: Unclear expressions, unsure approach, or nervous state may suggest this. Tension: Rainy day setting or awkward dressing might hint at nervousness. Angerous Expression: Sharp teeth and expressive mouths could indicate frustration. Desperation: Slow movements with hands trembling might show deep sadness. After considering typical emotional indicators, the most likely emotion is happiness, as shown by a peaceful demeanor and content expression.‚Äù
Deepseek delivered what had to have been the most incorrect answer. It went through basically every single emotion possible and concluded happiness. Happiness is probably the least justifiable emotion out fo the list for the man‚Äôs facial expression. This may imply that Deepseek can only recognize basic emotions like sadness and happiness, but is bad at recognizing more complex emotions like anxiety. Deepseek failed this test.


Claude
Claude‚Äôs response is the following:
‚ÄúThe person in this image appears to be experiencing distress, worry, or anxiety. Their body language - hands clasped over their mouth, intense focused expression, and hunched posture - suggests they are deep in concerned thought or potentially dealing with a troubling situation. They‚Äôre wearing a casual grey hoodie and sitting on what looks like a couch in a home setting with some plants visible in the background.‚Äù
Claude passed the test again. However, it is interesting that Claude continuously described the background/outfit of the people it analyzed.

title: LLMs and Emotional Recognition
text:
Conclusion
After testing each LLM on two different emotions, the results are pretty clear. ChatGPT is the most reliable at recognizing emotions‚Äîit consistently identified the correct emotions and gave solid reasoning based on body language and facial expressions. Claude did a decent job, getting one answer partially wrong but still managing to analyze body language fairly well. However, it had a weird tendency to describe background details, which didn‚Äôt really add much to its emotional analysis. Deepseek, on the other hand, struggled the most. While it got sadness right in the first test, its reasoning was questionable, and its response to the anxious man image was way off, somehow concluding he was happy.
Overall, this experiment shows that not all LLMs are equally good at recognizing emotions. ChatGPT handled it best, while Claude was hit-or-miss, and Deepseek had a tough time with more complex emotions. It‚Äôll be interesting to see how these models improve over time and whether they can develop a better understanding of human emotions beyond just the most basic ones.

title: The Scrabble Situation
text:
Scrabble Board Analysis: Testing ChatGPT‚Äôs Spatial Awareness and Letter Processing
The goal of this post is to test ChatGPT‚Äôs ability to solve Scrabble boards by analyzing the spatial layout of letters and available moves. We aim to assess how well ChatGPT can interpret images, recognize patterns, and generate optimal Scrabble moves based on board state.
To begin, we are starting with a relatively easy board where an optimal move is clearly available. This will allow us to gauge how well ChatGPT can recognize letter placements and suggest a high-scoring word.
Once we establish a baseline, we will pivot to a more complex board, increasing the difficulty to further evaluate ChatGPT‚Äôs spatial reasoning and text recognition capabilities in Scrabble.
By conducting this experiment, we hope to understand ChatGPT‚Äôs strengths and limitations in processing letter-based games and interpreting board layouts from images.



Current Scrabble Board:

ChatGPT will analyze the board and suggest the best possible move using the given letter tiles.


I'm sorry for any confusion, but as a text-based AI, I can't view images or screenshots. However, I can help you determine the best possible move if you provide details about the current state of the Scrabble board. Please describe the board position, including any existing words, premium squares, and your current letter rack. With that information, I'll be able to help you find the best move!




Scrabble Board Analysis: ChatGPT and Image Processing Limitations
During our initial test, we attempted to use a robocall approach to send an image of a Scrabble board to ChatGPT for analysis. However, we realized that the model does not support image-based processing via API calls. This means that ChatGPT, when accessed through the OpenAI API, cannot directly interpret images unless we extract text manually.



Workaround: Directly Uploading to ChatGPT
Since the robocall method was unsuccessful, we pivoted and uploaded the Scrabble board directly into ChatGPT‚Äôs interface. This allowed the model to process the image and generate an optimal move.
Here is the response generated by ChatGPT after analyzing the board:

As seen above, ChatGPT correctly identified the best possible move:
### Move: Place ‚ÄúLI‚Äù at (Column P, Row 10)

Word Formed: ‚ÄúLI‚Äù

Placement: The ‚ÄúL‚Äù at (P, 10) and ‚ÄúI‚Äù at (P, 11).

Points: This move extends an existing word while maximizing efficiency.




A Reminder: This is an Easy Case
While this response is correct, it‚Äôs important to note that this was a relatively simple board with only two tiles available. Our next test will involve a more complex board to further assess ChatGPT‚Äôs spatial reasoning, move optimization, and board evaluation skills.


Scrabble Board Analysis: Testing ChatGPT‚Äôs Spatial Awareness (Harder Board)
In our first test, we evaluated ChatGPT‚Äôs ability to analyze a Scrabble board and generate the best possible move. The first board was relatively simple, and ChatGPT provided a correct response.
Now, we are increasing the difficulty by presenting a more complex Scrabble board to assess ChatGPT‚Äôs spatial awareness and board evaluation capabilities. The scrabble board is shown below.




ChatGPT‚Äôs Suggested Move (Incorrect)
After analyzing the new Scrabble board, ChatGPT generated the following response:

At first glance, ChatGPT‚Äôs move appears valid, as it successfully connects letters to form a word. However, upon closer inspection, ChatGPT made a fundamental spatial mistake:

Mistake: ChatGPT assumed it could place a word downwards from ‚ÄúHUMVEE‚Äù.

Reality: ‚ÄúHUMVEE‚Äù is at the bottom row, meaning no tiles can be placed below it.

This error highlights a major limitation in ChatGPT‚Äôs ability to fully process board constraints. While the model can recognize words and create new ones using existing letters, it struggles with spatial awareness and positional limitations‚Äîwhich are crucial for a game like Scrabble.



Key Takeaways

ChatGPT understands letter placements but struggles with physical constraints on a board.

It can identify valid words using existing letters but may attempt moves that are spatially impossible.

Future improvements in AI‚Äôs spatial reasoning could allow for better board-game problem-solving.



Conclusion: Evaluating ChatGPT‚Äôs Scrabble Performance
Through this experiment, we tested ChatGPT‚Äôs ability to analyze Scrabble boards, generate optimal moves, and demonstrate spatial awareness. By presenting both an easy board and a more complex board, we identified several key strengths and limitations in how ChatGPT processes Scrabble gameplay.



Findings: Strengths and Weaknesses
‚úÖ Strengths: 1. Recognizes Existing Words on the Board: ChatGPT successfully identified letters on the board and could form new words using them.
2. Generates Valid Words Using Available Tiles: It was able to construct playable words based on the given tile set.
3. Acknowledges Special Tiles (Triple/Double Score Areas): The model noted the presence of premium scoring tiles (Triple Word Score, Double Letter Score) but did not optimize for them.
‚ùå Weaknesses: 1. Struggles with Spatial Awareness: In the second test, ChatGPT attempted to place a word downward when the board did not allow it, failing to recognize that ‚ÄúHUMVEE‚Äù was at the bottom row.
2. Does Not Maximize Score Potential: Although ChatGPT recognized the presence of premium tiles, it did not strategically place words to take full advantage of them. It defaulted to simple word placement rather than high-scoring strategies.
3. Cannot Calculate Exact Point Values: Unlike human Scrabble players who can calculate score efficiency, ChatGPT did not attempt to maximize points per move based on tile bonuses.



Final Takeaway
ChatGPT has a solid grasp of Scrabble fundamentals, particularly in word formation and board recognition. However, it lacks true strategic depth, particularly in leveraging high-scoring word placements and understanding board constraints.
While future AI improvements may address spatial limitations and strategic play, for now, human intuition and Scrabble expertise still outperform AI in high-level gameplay.

title: Can Chat GPT beat itself?
text: Chat GPT has a feature where it has multiple ‚ÄúCustom GPTs‚Äù on its site; these include ‚ÄúCode Copilot,‚ÄùSora‚Äù, and today‚Äôs star ‚ÄúAI Humanizer.‚Äù I will initially feed it an outline for my Op-Ed from my freshman year writing seminar and tell it to write an Op-ed using it. Then I am going to run it through GPT 0 and see the AI result. After that, I will put it through ‚ÄúAI Humanizer‚Äù and other GPT humanizer bots to see if it can lower the overall AI score or even get through the detector altogether.

I Prompted it with the following:
‚ÄúThis returned an AI score of 78% AI-generated 1% Mixed 21% Human
Could you humanize it more.‚Äù
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Stop Letting Algorithms Decide Who Gets Policed By Ethan Roytman
Imagine being flagged as a potential criminal‚Äînot because of something you did, but because of where you live or how often police have historically shown up in your neighborhood. That‚Äôs the reality for too many people living in cities across the U.S., thanks to a growing reliance on predictive policing.
At first glance, predictive policing sounds like a smart use of technology. Feed crime data into a computer, let it find patterns, and use those patterns to stop crimes before they happen. Sounds efficient, right?
But here‚Äôs the problem: the data being used isn‚Äôt neutral. It reflects decades of over-policing in predominantly Black, Latino, and low-income neighborhoods. So when these algorithms predict where police should go next, they usually point right back to the same communities that have been under surveillance for years. It‚Äôs not a smarter system‚Äîit‚Äôs a loop. And the people caught in it are often the ones already struggling under the weight of systemic inequality.
Take a neighborhood with a long history of police presence. Maybe crime gets reported more often there‚Äînot because people are committing more crimes, but because police are constantly around, stopping people, writing things up. The algorithm picks up on this and flags the area as ‚Äúhigh risk,‚Äù leading to even more patrols. It becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy.
Meanwhile, we‚Äôre not solving anything. Predictive policing doesn‚Äôt ask why crime happens. It doesn‚Äôt deal with poverty, joblessness, poor education, or the lack of mental health care. It doesn‚Äôt offer hope, opportunity, or safety in any meaningful sense. It just sends more officers into places already stretched thin, while ignoring the deeper reasons people turn to crime in the first place.
Some people argue these algorithms help make police work more effective. That they spot patterns officers might miss. That they save time, resources, and money. But if the patterns are built on flawed data, what are we really improving? Efficiency isn‚Äôt a virtue if it‚Äôs just making inequality faster.
We‚Äôve reached a point where it‚Äôs not enough to ask whether technology works‚Äîwe have to ask what kind of society it‚Äôs helping us build. And right now, predictive policing is pushing us further away from justice, not closer to it.
Ending the use of these algorithms doesn‚Äôt mean giving up on public safety. It means rethinking what real safety looks like. It means investing in schools, after-school programs, community centers, jobs. It means understanding that safety isn‚Äôt just about stopping bad things from happening‚Äîit‚Äôs about making good things possible in the first place.
Algorithms don‚Äôt have to be villains. But they‚Äôre only as fair as the data we feed them‚Äîand our criminal justice data is full of bias. Until we fix that, we shouldn‚Äôt be using machines to make decisions that affect real people‚Äôs lives.
We have the chance to break the cycle. Let‚Äôs stop relying on predictive policing and start investing in what truly keeps communities safe.‚Äù

title: A Deep Dive into Deep Research
text:
This post will be somewhat unconventional. The nature of deep research is that it takes 5-15 minutes to do a deep dive into the internet and generates around 5000 words of analysis. I prompted Chat GPT 4.5 and Deep Research to create an analysis of Trump‚Äôs first 50 days in office focused on policy changes, executive orders, and socio-economic impact.
Chat GPT 4.5 Response is below:
In the first 50 days of President Donald Trump‚Äôs second term, his administration enacted a series of policy changes and executive orders with significant socio-economic implications.
Policy Changes and Executive Orders

Immigration: On his first day, President Trump declared a national emergency at the U.S.-Mexico border, reinstated the ‚Äúremain in Mexico‚Äù policy, and designated Mexican drug cartels as terrorist organizations. He also signed an order to end birthright citizenship for descendants of illegal immigrants.
Trade and Tariffs: The administration imposed 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum imports and a 10% tariff on imports from China, aiming to reduce the flow of fentanyl into the U.S. Additionally, plans for reciprocal tariffs on foreign nations were announced, set to take effect in April.
Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) Programs: An executive order was issued to dismantle DEI initiatives within the federal government, affecting workplace inclusivity efforts.
Energy and Environmental Policies: The administration declared a national energy emergency favoring fossil fuel production, rolled back electric vehicle targets, and halted wind energy projects.

Socio-Economic Impact

Economic Uncertainty: The new tariffs and strained international relations have contributed to economic uncertainty. Business and consumer sentiment have declined, manufacturing has weakened, and stock prices have dropped, potentially slowing consumer spending.
Stock Market Performance: The stock market experienced its worst start since 2009, with the S&P 500 index falling by 6.4%, the Nasdaq Composite dropping by 11%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average decreasing by 3.6%. This decline reflects investor concerns over potential economic downturns and policy ambiguities.
Consumer Prices and Inflation: The tariffs are expected to raise prices on various goods, fueling inflation and economic instability. Companies may pass on increased costs to consumers, leading to reduced consumer spending and confidence.
Employment: While employment growth persists, new tariffs and retaliatory actions may reverse this trend. The Federal Reserve faces challenges in navigating these uncertainties, with increased near-term recession risks.
International Relations: The administration‚Äôs policies have strained relations with key trading partners, leading to retaliatory measures. For example, Canadian travel to the U.S. has significantly declined following tariff tensions, potentially resulting in economic losses for the U.S. tourism industry.

In summary, President Trump‚Äôs initial 50 days have been marked by assertive policy shifts and executive actions, leading to notable socio-economic consequences. The long-term effects of these policies remain to be seen as the administration continues to navigate complex domestic and international challenges.

title: A Deep Dive into Deep Research
text:
Policy Changes

Domestic Policy Shifts
Trump rapidly reversed many of his predecessor‚Äôs domestic policies and introduced new initiatives reflecting his 2016‚Äì2020 agenda. Immigration enforcement tightened significantly. On Day¬†1, Trump signed orders to ‚ÄúSecure Our Borders‚Äù and ‚ÄúProtect the American People Against Invasion,‚Äù reinstating strict border controls and nullifying several of President Biden‚Äôs 2021 immigration directives (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). These actions restarted border wall construction and imposed tougher asylum and deportation rules, prompting legal challenges by immigrant advocacy groups. Trump also moved to realign the U.S. refugee program, slashing refugee admissions and revoking Biden‚Äôs earlier refugee order (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders).
Economic and regulatory policy took a sharp turn. The administration imposed a regulatory freeze and launched a ‚ÄúDepartment of Government Efficiency‚Äù initiative to shrink the federal bureaucracy (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). A hiring near-freeze was implemented alongside plans to cut tens of thousands of federal jobs (e.g.¬†a leaked memo outlined 80,000 layoffs at the VA alone) (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). High-profile business advisor Elon Musk was tasked to lead the efficiency drive, even appearing with Trump in Congress as head of the new initiative (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Trump‚Äôs team also signaled intent to abolish the Department of Education, with a draft executive order directing the Education Secretary to plan the department‚Äôs closure (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). In tandem, Trump issued orders to ‚ÄúEnd Radical Indoctrination‚Äù in schools and promote ‚Äúpatriotic education,‚Äù targeting diversity curricula and COVID-related school policies (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). These moves pleased conservative constituencies but alarmed educators and civil rights groups.
The administration swiftly dismantled diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) programs across the government. One early order revoked dozens of prior executive orders dating back to the 1960s that had mandated affirmative action and diversity initiatives (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Trump framed these reversals as ‚Äúrestoring merit-based opportunity,‚Äù effectively ending affirmative action requirements for federal contractors and agencies. He also ordered the elimination of federal ‚ÄúDEI‚Äù training and offices as ‚Äúillegal and immoral discrimination programs‚Äù (Executive Order: Ending Radical And Wasteful Government DEI ‚Ä¶). Additionally, Trump enforced a strict interpretation of gender and reproductive policies: he banned transgender women from women‚Äôs sports via executive order (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), directed federal agencies to recognize only biological sex in policy (‚Äúrestoring biological truth‚Äù) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), and moved to enforce the Hyde Amendment by barring federal funds for abortion-related services (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Each of these actions was met with praise from social conservatives and protests from LGBTQ and women‚Äôs rights advocates.
Trump‚Äôs energy and environmental policy reversed course from the prior administration. He declared a ‚ÄúNational Energy Emergency‚Äù on Day¬†1 to boost fossil fuel production (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) and signed an expansive ‚ÄúUnleashing American Energy‚Äù order that revoked a host of Biden-era climate initiatives (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). This order opened federal lands and offshore areas to oil and gas drilling, rolled back emissions regulations, and scrapped considerations of climate change in agency decisions (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). The administration also greenlit projects like the Keystone XL pipeline and Arctic oil development (‚ÄúUnleashing Alaska‚Äôs Resource Potential‚Äù) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Fossil fuel industries and allied lawmakers applauded these steps, while environmental groups decried the U.S. exit from international climate efforts (the Day¬†1 order ‚ÄúPutting America First in International Environmental Agreements‚Äù signaled withdrawal from the Paris Accord commitments) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders).
Law and order policies were another focus. Trump moved to reinstate federal executions, ending a de facto moratorium on the death penalty (‚ÄúRestoring the Death Penalty‚Äù) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). He championed gun rights with an order ‚ÄúProtecting Second Amendment Rights‚Äù that rolled back federal gun-control efforts (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). In addition, he established a White House faith-based office and ordered federal agencies to combat ‚Äúanti-Christian bias,‚Äù signaling support for religious conservatives (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Each of these policy shifts set a new direction for federal agencies and often directly countermanded Biden administration priorities.


Foreign Policy Shifts
Trump‚Äôs early foreign policy moves reflected an ‚ÄúAmerica First‚Äù approach marked by retrenchment from global institutions and confrontational trade measures. Immediately upon taking office, he withdrew the United States from the World Health Organization (WHO) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), reversing the prior re-entry and cutting off U.S. funding to WHO. He also issued an order to ‚Äúwithdraw from and review support for certain United Nations organizations‚Äù, putting U.N.-affiliated agencies on notice and halting funds to groups like the National Endowment for Democracy (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Allies and international observers expressed concern at these steps, warning of diminished U.S. influence in global health and democracy promotion.
Trump quickly upended U.S. trade policy. In late January and early February, he signed a series of orders imposing new tariffs and duties: targeting China‚Äôs supply of fentanyl-related chemicals, he levied a tariff on Chinese goods to pressure Beijing (‚ÄúImposing Duties to Address the Synthetic Opioid Supply Chain in China‚Äù) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders); to compel Mexico to curb illegal migration, he announced tariffs on Mexican exports (‚ÄúDuties to Address the Situation at Our Southern Border‚Äù) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders); and he placed duties on Canadian imports citing cross-border drug flows (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). By early March, this escalated into a full-fledged trade war, as Trump hiked tariffs on China to 20% and slapped a new 25% duty on most Canadian and Mexican imports (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). He partially walked back some tariffs (granting a short-term exemption for goods under the USMCA rules of origin) amid frantic negotiations (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). Nonetheless, these actions marked ‚Äúthe end of the zero-tariff era,‚Äù as Trump declared, and signaled a return to protectionism (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). U.S. farmers, in particular, were warned to ‚Äúbear with‚Äù the short-term pain of lost export markets, as Trump acknowledged an adjustment period ahead (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). Indeed, European and other trading partners retaliated with tariffs of their own by March (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters), straining relations with traditional allies.
Beyond trade, Trump pursued an aggressive stance on national security. He re-designated the Yemeni rebel group Ansar Allah (the Houthis) as a Foreign Terrorist Organization (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), reversing a Biden-era policy to delist them, despite humanitarian concerns in Yemen. He also sanctioned the International Criminal Court (ICC) and its officials (‚ÄúImposing Sanctions on the ICC‚Äù), reviving a dispute over ICC probes of U.S. personnel (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). In the Middle East, Trump strengthened ties with Israel‚Äôs security establishment ‚Äì for example, announcing an ‚ÄúIron Dome for America‚Äù program to develop U.S. missile defenses modeled on Israel‚Äôs system (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). At the same time, he took a hard line against groups viewed as threats: a Day¬†1 order directed the government to treat foreign drug cartels akin to terrorist organizations, facilitating tougher action against them (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). He also signaled a more combative posture toward adversaries in cyberspace and technology, ordering a review to ban or restrict apps like TikTok that are controlled by foreign rivals (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders).
Overall, Trump‚Äôs first 50 days saw a dramatic reorientation of U.S. policy. Domestically, his administration veered sharply right on immigration, social issues, and deregulation, while internationally it embraced unilateralism and economic nationalism. Many changes were enacted unilaterally via executive fiat, setting the stage for legal battles and political clashes in the months ahead.

section: Executive Orders: Key Actions and Consequences
text:
Executive Orders: Key Actions and Consequences
President Trump heavily relied on executive orders (EOs) to enact his agenda swiftly. By March 13, he had signed 82 EOs in his first 50 days, an unprecedented pace (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). (For comparison, this nearly matched the total number of EOs in his entire first term.) He issued 26 EOs on Inauguration Day alone (Executive Order: Securing Our Borders (Donald Trump, 2025)). These orders targeted a wide range of policies. Below are some of the most significant EOs from this period, along with their intent and immediate effects:

‚ÄúInitial Rescissions of Harmful EOs and Actions‚Äù (EO 14148, Jan 20, 2025): This sweeping Day¬†1 order nullified many of President Biden‚Äôs executive orders on climate, equity, immigration, and more (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It revoked at least 17 orders signed in 2021 (including orders on racial equity, climate regulations, and immigration) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Intent: Erase the prior administration‚Äôs policy legacy in one stroke. Immediate consequence: Dozens of federal initiatives (from rejoining the Paris Climate Accord to DEI programs in agencies) were halted or reversed overnight, prompting confusion within agencies and celebratory statements from Trump allies who opposed those initiatives.
‚ÄúSecuring Our Borders‚Äù (EO 14165, Jan 20, 2025): One of several immigration orders signed immediately, it directed the construction of new border barriers and deployment of resources to the southern border (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It also ended the practice of catch-and-release and reinstated Trump-era asylum restrictions that Biden had rolled back. Intent: Fulfill campaign promises to crack down on illegal immigration and ‚Äúfinish the wall.‚Äù Consequences: Within days, contractors were notified to resume border wall projects, and border patrol began operating under tougher rules. Immigration advocacy groups filed lawsuits, and by mid-February, federal courts were reviewing challenges to these policies on humanitarian and legal grounds (e.g., questioning the reinstated asylum limits).
‚ÄúProtecting the United States From Foreign Terrorists‚Äù (EO 14161, Jan 20, 2025): This order effectively reimposed a travel ban by suspending entry of individuals from several countries deemed high-risk for terrorism (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It expanded on Trump‚Äôs 2017 travel ban, adding new vetting measures. Intent: Prevent terrorist infiltration by tightening visa issuance and entry from certain Middle Eastern and African nations. Immediate consequence: Travel from the affected countries was abruptly halted, stranding some travelers and drawing protest from civil liberties groups. The order faced immediate court challenges, recalling the legal battles from 2017.
‚ÄúUnleashing American Energy‚Äù (EO 14154, Jan 20, 2025): A comprehensive energy order that rolled back environmental regulations and prioritized fossil fuel development (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It revoked numerous climate-related orders (11 of Biden‚Äôs climate EOs were listed for revocation) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) and instructed agencies to expedite permits for oil, gas, and coal projects. Intent: Promote energy independence and economic growth by removing ‚Äúburdensome‚Äù green regulations. Consequences: The Department of Interior promptly restarted oil lease sales on federal land, and the EPA moved to loosen emissions standards. Oil and gas companies‚Äô stock prices rose on anticipation of friendlier policy, while environmental organizations mobilized opposition, with some states preparing lawsuits citing environmental harm.
‚ÄúDepartment of Government Efficiency‚Äù Initiative (EO 14158, Jan 20, 2025): This order created a new cross-agency task force (dubbed the Department of Government Efficiency, or ‚ÄúDOGE‚Äù) to cut federal jobs, slash regulations, and reorganize agencies (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Elon Musk was appointed as an adviser to this effort, reflecting Trump‚Äôs outsourcing of innovation to private-sector figures (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Intent: Radically shrink the federal bureaucracy and reduce government spending. Immediate consequence: Agencies instituted near-freezes on hiring and began identifying programs for cuts. Federal employee unions reacted with outrage ‚Äì by early March, union-led protests at state capitols and in D.C. drew thousands, decrying ‚Äúillegal mass firings‚Äù and the influence of Musk in government (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO) (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Multiple lawsuits were filed claiming that summary dismissals of civil servants violated federal law, and some judges issued initial injunctions to temporarily halt certain layoffs (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press).
‚ÄúEnding Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs‚Äù (EO 14151, Jan 20, 2025): This order abolished diversity, equity, and inclusion programs in federal agencies, labeling them as ideological indoctrination (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). It rescinded mandates that agencies consider diversity in hiring and contracting. Intent: Remove what Trump viewed as politicized ‚Äúwoke‚Äù programs from government. Consequences: Agencies like the State Department and Pentagon immediately canceled unconscious bias trainings and disbanded DEI councils. Supporters argued this restored focus on merit, but critics within and outside government warned it would foster discrimination. The abrupt cancellation of longstanding programs also led to uncertainty in compliance for federal contractors until guidance was clarified.
‚ÄúWithdrawing the U.S. from the WHO‚Äù (EO 14155, Jan 20, 2025): As part of Trump‚Äôs foreign policy shift, this order formally initiated U.S. withdrawal from the World Health Organization and redirected global health funds elsewhere (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Intent: Protest and cut ties with an international body Trump accused of mismanagement (echoing his 2020 stance during COVID-19). Immediate consequence: The State Department halted the disbursement of U.S. dues to WHO. Health experts warned that American absence could weaken global pandemic preparedness. By late February, Congress was debating measures to possibly override this decision, and some bipartisan concern emerged about losing influence to China in the WHO.
Tariff Orders (‚ÄúImposing Duties‚Äù series, Feb¬†1‚ÄìFeb¬†6, 2025): Trump issued multiple executive orders to levy tariffs on imports from China, Mexico, and Canada under various justifications (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). For example, EO¬†14195 imposed tariffs on Chinese goods in response to fentanyl trafficking (Federal Register :: Executive Orders), and EO¬†14194 put duties on Mexican imports to pressure Mexico on migration (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Intent: Use executive authority to reshape trade terms and compel foreign cooperation on U.S. priorities. Consequences: These unilateral tariffs roiled markets and foreign relations. China and Mexico threatened retaliation, and Canada prepared WTO complaints. U.S. companies depending on imported inputs faced higher costs, and trade associations warned of supply chain disruptions. Within a month, Trump temporarily eased some tariffs amid legal scrutiny and negotiations (illustrating the on-and-off ‚Äúwhiplash‚Äù nature of his trade actions (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters)).

Each of these executive orders had immediate ripple effects. Supporters of Trump‚Äôs actions praised the decisive implementation of campaign promises. Opponents, however, turned to the courts: in fact, 113 lawsuits were filed in the first 50 days against various Trump policies (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). Judges issued early injunctions on some orders (e.g.¬†blocking the freeze of certain congressionally approved funds and the firing of independent officials) (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). The flurry of EOs underscored Trump‚Äôs strategy of governing by executive action and set the tone for a contentious start to the term.

title: A Deep Dive into Deep Research
text:
Socio-Economic Impact
Trump‚Äôs initial policy shifts and orders had measurable impacts on economic indicators, business sentiment, and society in early 2025. The table below summarizes key economic metrics from the start of the term:



Indicator
Jan 2025
Feb‚ÄìMar 2025
Trend/Notes




Unemployment Rate
4.0% (Jan) ([US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts
Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/markets/us/us-job-openings-increase-january-layoffs-decline-2025-03-11/#:~:text=WASHINGTON%2C%20March%2011%20%28Reuters%29%20,sharp%20slowdown%20in%20economic%20activity))
4.1% (Feb) (February 2025 Jobs Report: Economy Adds 151K Jobs - J.P. Morgan)

~125,000 (Jan) (The US economy added 151,000 jobs last month and the ‚Ä¶ - CNN)

Inflation (CPI, YoY)
3.0% (Jan) ([US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices
Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/markets/us/us-consumer-price-growth-slows-february-2025-03-12/#:~:text=egg%20prices%20on%20his%20first,day%20in%20office))
2.8% (Feb) ([US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices


Small Business Optimism

‚âà10% drop; post-election gains erased by trade war ([US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts



¬π Illustrative index values: NFIB Small Business Optimism Index (Dec 2024 vs Feb 2025).
¬≤ Approximate S&P¬†500 levels: reflecting that investors ‚Äúwiped out all the gains‚Äù made after Trump‚Äôs election by early March (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters).
As shown above, the labor market remained resilient but showed signs of cooling. The U.S. added an estimated 276,000 jobs in January and February combined, about 19% fewer than the same period a year prior (U.S. Added 151,000 Jobs As Unemployment Rose To 4.1 ‚Ä¶ - Forbes). The unemployment rate in February edged up to 4.1% from 4.0%, indicating a modest softening (The US economy added 151,000 jobs last month and the ‚Ä¶ - CNN). Notably, government employment fell by tens of thousands as federal agencies began implementing Trump‚Äôs workforce cuts. In fact, Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúDOGE‚Äù layoffs helped push U.S. layoff figures to post-pandemic highs in early 2025, according to market observers (U.S. adds 151000 jobs, but Trump tumult to weigh on hiring plans). Private hiring was described as ‚Äútepid‚Äù ‚Äì many businesses took a wait-and-see stance amid the new administration‚Äôs unpredictable policy moves (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters).
Inflation decelerated in the first two months. Consumer prices were up 2.8% year-over-year in February, down from 3.0% in January (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters), continuing a downward trend. However, economists cautioned that this ‚Äútame‚Äù inflation picture might be short-lived, because the February data did not yet reflect Trump‚Äôs tariff actions (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). The cascade of new import duties in March caused a spike in inflation expectations (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). Analysts predicted that upcoming reports would show price increases for affected goods, and the Federal Reserve, which had paused interest rate moves, might consider rate cuts if trade tensions slowed growth (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters) (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). Indeed, Trump‚Äôs trade war jolted financial markets: by mid-March, stock indices had suffered heavy losses as trade tensions threatened the economic expansion (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters). Investors reacted to Trump‚Äôs on-again/off-again tariff announcements with volatility. Reuters reported that by March 11, stocks had ‚Äúwiped out all the gains‚Äù made in the relief rally after Trump‚Äôs November election victory (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters). Fears of a recession increased as businesses warned that higher import costs and foreign retaliation could hurt profits (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters).
Business sentiment turned more cautious. The NFIB small business confidence index and other surveys fell for three consecutive months, reaching their lowest since early 2024 (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters). According to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and other groups, companies were concerned about the uncertainty of Trump‚Äôs policies ‚Äì especially trade policy ‚Äúwhiplash‚Äù and the aggressive regulatory swings. One report noted that Trump‚Äôs unpredictable tariffs ‚Äúshook business and consumer confidence‚Äù, making firms hesitant to hire or invest until policies stabilized (US job openings rise, layoffs low before Trump policy shifts | Reuters). Sectors like agriculture and manufacturing, which are sensitive to trade, grew worried about export markets. At the same time, industries favored by Trump‚Äôs agenda experienced optimism: oil and gas executives, for example, voiced confidence that deregulation would boost production and profits, and defense contractors anticipated higher military spending given Trump‚Äôs promises to ‚Äúrestore America‚Äôs fighting force‚Äù (per his executive orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders) (Federal Register :: Executive Orders). Still, the prevailing mood in the broader business community was one of caution due to the rapid and sweeping nature of changes.
Social and political impacts were dramatic in this initial period. Trump‚Äôs actions prompted intense reactions across the country. Supporters rallied behind the President‚Äôs swift fulfillment of campaign promises, but opposition mobilized quickly. In fact, all 50 states saw protests against Trump‚Äôs early policies. On February 5, a grassroots network organized coordinated rallies at every state capitol (the ‚Äú50501 Movement‚Äù) to decry Trump‚Äôs executive orders and the Project 2025 agenda (50 states, 50 protests against Project 2025, Trump orders planned for Feb.¬†5 | FOX 9 Minneapolis-St.¬†Paul) (50 states, 50 protests against Project 2025, Trump orders planned for Feb.¬†5 | FOX 9 Minneapolis-St.¬†Paul). Less than a fortnight later, on Presidents‚Äô Day, thousands more protesters gathered in cities nationwide for ‚ÄúNot My President‚Äôs Day‚Äù demonstrations. They protested what organizers called ‚Äúthe antidemocratic and illegal actions‚Äù of the Trump administration (‚ÄòNot My President‚Äôs Day‚Äô: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump - The Atlantic). Many demonstrators specifically targeted Elon Musk‚Äôs role and the mass federal layoffs, chanting slogans against autocracy and carrying signs like ‚ÄúNo Kings!‚Äù (‚ÄòNot My President‚Äôs Day‚Äô: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump - The Atlantic).
(‚ÄòNot My President‚Äôs Day‚Äô: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump) Protesters rally near the U.S. Capitol on Presidents‚Äô Day 2025 against President Trump‚Äôs early agenda. An upside-down American flag (a sign of distress) is flown as demonstrators oppose what they call ‚Äúantidemocratic‚Äù actions by the administration (‚ÄòNot My President‚Äôs Day‚Äô: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump - The Atlantic).
Legal challenges also surged as part of the social response. As noted, over 100 lawsuits were filed in the first several weeks, coming from states, NGOs, and affected individuals (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). Courts began to act as a check: for example, a federal judge blocked the administration from firing a member of the NLRB without cause, questioning Trump‚Äôs broad claim of removal power (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO). Another court ordered the temporary unfreezing of certain congressionally appropriated funds that the administration had tried to halt (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO) (such as a case where the National Endowment for Democracy sued over $239¬†million in withheld grants). These early legal interventions slowed some of Trump‚Äôs initiatives, though many cases remained to be decided.
On the whole, the socio-economic landscape in early 2025 was one of heightened turbulence. Economic indicators showed a recovery that was still intact but facing new headwinds from protectionist policies. Financial markets and business leaders signaled concern over policy instability, even as Trump touted the stock market when it rose and downplayed downturns as ‚Äúadjustments.‚Äù Socially, the country experienced deepening polarization: Trump‚Äôs base remained energized by his rapid actions, while opponents mounted a ‚Äúresistance‚Äù that included nationwide protests, legal battles, and public campaigns to defend vulnerable communities (immigrants, LGBTQ individuals, etc.) affected by the new policies.
Objectively, by the 50th day of Trump‚Äôs term, significant change was underway. The administration claimed ‚Äúswift and unrelenting‚Äù progress on its agenda (Today‚Äôs AFL-CIO press clips | Kentucky State AFL-CIO), pointing to dozens of fulfilled promises such as tax cut proposals (unveiled in outline to Congress) and the rollback of liberal policies. Economic data showed some positive signs like lower inflation, but also flashing warnings in sentiment and markets. The country‚Äôs political discourse had shifted to debates over executive power, with Trump asserting expansive authority to reshape government and critics arguing he was overstepping constitutional bounds. In just 50 days, Trump ‚Äúaccomplished more‚Ä¶than most administrations accomplish in four or eight years,‚Äù he boasted to Congress (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press). Whether one views that as a list of achievements or alarms, there is no doubt that the first 50 days of 2025 set a decisive and contentious tone ‚Äì one that would define the trajectory of the Trump administration and its impact on the United States.
Sources: This analysis is based on reporting from reputable outlets and official records, including executive order texts in the Federal Register, news analyses by Reuters, NPR, Forbes, and others, economic data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and contemporary accounts of public and legal responses. Key references are cited in the text for verification (US consumer inflation slows in February; tariffs expected to boost prices | Reuters) (Trump sets torrid pace in first 50 days in office | Capital Press) (‚ÄòNot My President‚Äôs Day‚Äô: Thousands Gather in Protest Against Trump - The Atlantic), ensuring an objective and comprehensive overview of President Trump‚Äôs early term policies and their consequences.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text: Today is my dog Louis‚Äôs 8th Birthday!!! In honor of him, this post will be centered around Dalle‚Äôs ability to recreate images - specifically images of him. We will be both analyzing the accuracy of the image that is recreated and also noticing the prompt it creates to describe the image.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text: Today is my dog Louis‚Äôs 8th Birthday!!! In honor of him, this post will be centered around Dalle‚Äôs ability to recreate images - specifically images of him. We will be both analyzing the accuracy of the image that is recreated and also noticing the prompt it creates to describe the image.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text:
LLAMA Louis
Below is the first picture we will be tasking Dalle to recreate. I give it the initial prompt of the following: ‚ÄúToday we are going trying to recreate images of my dog Louis. I want you to pay as much detail to all of the items in the image as well as the orientation of the dog. We will start out with recreating this uploaded image.‚Äù
Below is the image:

When I first put into Chatgpt it recreated it as the following:

Not only did they butcher Louis‚Äôs face, but they also made the plushy the wrong type of animal. Because of this, I went to the prompt Chat GPT generated every time it generated an image. It displayed the following: ‚ÄúA detailed recreation of a cozy indoor scene featuring a gray standard poodle lying on a couch. The dog rests its head gently on a brown plush toy with pink feet and a pink face, which has visible wear. The couch is covered with a soft white blanket that has black striped patterns. The dog‚Äôs body is stretched out comfortably, with a relaxed and peaceful expression. The lighting is soft and warm, enhancing the calm atmosphere of the scene.‚Äù
From the description you can realize that the reason ChatGPT messaged it up is that it simplified the llamma stuffed animal to just a ‚Äúplush toy.‚Äù This can suggest two things a) ChatGPT has a limited amount of stimuli it can describe and recreate, b) Chat GPT doesn‚Äôt have the ability to realize what kind of animal the plush toy is, or C) it doesn‚Äôt regard it as an important detail.
To test these options I told ChatGPT ‚Äúits a llamma not a dog plush toy‚Äù and it generated the following image:

This image is significantly more accurate than the first generation. Not only did it get the toy correct, it also mimics Louis‚Äôs facial expression and the zoom of the picture better. This POTENTAILLY suggests that Chat GPT may have returned to the original reference when creating the llama to then incorporate said llama into the recreation. If that is what Chat GPT then it would help us rule out some of the hypotheses from the last image. It would prove that Chatgpt does have the ability to realize what kind of animal the plush toy is and that it also isn‚Äôt limited on the amount of stimulus it can generate. Thus, it would mean that on the original scan of the image - it didn‚Äôt regard the type of animal the toy was as an important detail.
To figure this out lets run through more scenarios.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text:
Blanket Louis
In this trial, we are going to give Chatgpt a relatively simpler picture of Louis in a blanket. As seen in the picture below, the blanket has a floral pattern. I‚Äôm curious to see the extent to which Chatgpt mirrors this pattern. This will help us see if it messed up the Llamma last time because there were too many factors or because it generally doesn‚Äôt notice specific details until a second attempt.
Image I gave Chatgpt:

Recreated Image:

It generated the following image description: ‚ÄúA detailed recreation of a calm and cozy indoor scene featuring a gray standard poodle lying curled up comfortably on a white bed. The poodle is partially covered with a soft blanket that has a white background and vibrant floral patterns in pink, green, and blue. The dog‚Äôs head rests gently on the bed, with its fluffy tail visible and fur neatly groomed. The lighting is natural, soft, and gentle, emphasizing a relaxing atmosphere.‚Äù
While this recreation isn‚Äôt perfect, it does include the floral pattern displayed on the rug; partially disproving the initial theory that GPT just doesn‚Äôt care about specific details of items. Rather it probably only registers specific details about a select number of items - which is why it didn‚Äôt note the toy type in the last one. The fact that each description is also the same length, gives credit to this idea of a finite amount of specific details. In every picture it is still interesting to note that while the position has been close, it hasn‚Äôt been entirely accurate. Thus, for the final trial I will give it a very simple image.

title: Happy Birthday Louis!
text:
Lounging Louis
The final trial is going to be a simple image of Louis in an unconventional position that Chat GPT usually hasn‚Äôt been able to match in previous trials. I‚Äôll put the image, recreation, and description below.
Image I gave Chatgpt:

Recreated Image:

It generated the following image description: ‚ÄúA cozy indoor scene featuring a gray standard poodle lying on its back with all four paws in the air. The dog rests on a white bed with a quilted texture. The room has soft lighting coming through a window with white blinds, allowing a view of the sky outside. The dog‚Äôs body is relaxed and sprawled out comfortably on the bed, with its fluffy fur and groomed poodle style. The calm atmosphere is enhanced by the clean and minimalistic setting.‚Äù
The theory of the consistent image description length holds true in this trial as well. The description also relatively mirrors the same format in each of the pictures. All 3 start with ‚Äúindoor scene‚Äù and end with a description of the atmosphere and setting. This suggests that there is a finite amount of details per image and they will find or limit details to reach that limit. This is further proven by the fact that it had extra descriptions of Louis‚Äôs positioning in this picture.

Conclusion
This experiment reaffirmed how we learned LLMs process images in class; they scan through the image, noting the key components, and create an image based on that. In this series of trials, Chat GPT was asked to recreate images. Every time it was asked, it would create a description of similar length noting key things in the original image. Oftentimes, it would miss key details in the recreation, but when guided to fix said mistakes - it would do a pretty good job. This shows that while Chat GPT is good at recognizing details in images, but potentially struggles at sorting out which details are key to recreating an image. It also demonstrates that Chat GPT has a limited amount of information it can take in about an image, meaning the more complex an image the less likely it is to recreate it accurately.
